title: Add Standard Groupings
text: light sample sizes, breakdowns PSRC’s Household Travel Survey instrument often involve category groupings less granular reported level detail. psrc.travelsurvey functions provide commonly utilized groupings, can considered agency standard variables interest. Although new variable specific one unit analysis (.e. hh, person, day, trip, vehicle), first argument grouping function entire hts_data object, order facilitate piping. one standard grouping exists variable, function returns , convenience; can distinguished suffix denoting number categories. functions require disaggregate input variable requested earlier get_psrc_hts() call. input variable output variable included resulting hts_data object. Currently, following functions exist, along required input variable.
code: library(psrc.travelsurvey) library(magrittr) library(data.table)  # Specify which variables to retrieve vars <- c("age", "hhsize")  # Retrieve the data hts_data <- get_psrc_hts(survey_year=2023, survey_vars = vars)   # Add standard groupings for age and household size # -- Notice age and hhsize use different tables (person, hh) # -- but you don't need to worry about that; the package knows hts_data <- hts_data %>%    hts_bin_age() %>%   hts_bin_hhsize() #> [1] "`age` variable missing from data"  hts_data$person[, head(.SD), .SDcols=patterns("^age")] #>            age #>          <ord> #> 1: 45-54 years #> 2: 16-17 years #> 3: 12-15 years #> 4: 35-44 years #> 5: 25-34 years #> 6: 45-54 years

title: Retrieve and summarize data
text: psrc.travelsurvey package meant complement enhance travelSurveyTools package PSRC users. delivers data hts_data format appropriate input subsequent travelSurveyTools functions. also provides wrapper functions provide PSRC defaults travelSurveyTools functions, resulting simpler workflows fewer required arguments. psrc.travelsurvey constrained extent fitting travelSurveyTools system, suggestions features functions ’d find helpful, please contact authors ’ll see can implement .

title: Retrieve and summarize data
text: Since psrc.travelsurvey uses Elmer, agency’s central database, retrieve PSRC household travel survey data ’ll need connected (office via VPN). use get_psrc_hts(), takes two arguments: survey_years - vector one years; default available .e., c(2017,2019,2021,2023) writing. survey_vars - vector variable names (regardless table occur) return object list separate data.table elements potential unit analysis, .e. household (hh), person, day, trip, vehicle. travelSurveyTools package workflow uses central object related independent variable summaries. can include full set variables summaries, ’s unnecessary request separate data objects feed separate summary data table. also supports multiyear summaries (trends/comparisons) via survey_year field. efficiency, get_psrc_hts() requests variables specify, must know precise names. lookup function, psrc_hts_varsearch() can assist; takes single string argument codebook search term matches either variable name description fields. Regular expressions supported complex searches; example, word boundary operator \\b can used omit vehicle model results searching “mode”. browse entire variable list, open internal data object variable_list: Note: unnecessary include survey year, table ids, weights, survey stratification variable (sample_segment) survey_vars argument; since necessary later steps, get_psrc_hts() includes implicitly. Factor variables levels applied codebook, missing skip-value codes recoded NA.

title: Retrieve and summarize data
text: summarize data, use psrc_hts_stat(). four primary arguments, one option. arguments : hts_data - hts_data object analysis_unit - string specifying scale statistics calculated, either “hh”, “person”, “day”,“trip”, “vehicle”. group_vars - grouping variables, nesting order (share summaries calculated per categories variable listed last). stat_var (optional) - Numeric variable min/max/median/mean desired; omit count/share summaries. example, ’ll retrieve following survey variables, one count/share summary, one numeric summary. Notice, travelSurveyTools handles relational element data, tables lower organizational heirarchy (like trips) inherit attributes (hh); handy feature avoids unnecessary data duplication among tables. Average daily trip rates average daily VMT rates special cases summary functions, described vignette.
code: library(psrc.travelsurvey) library(data.table)  # Specify which variables to retrieve vars <- c("hhsize", "employment", "commute_mode", "dest_purpose",           "mode_class_5", "distance_miles")  # Retrieve the data hts_data <- get_psrc_hts(survey_vars = vars)  # default includes all survey_years    # Calculate a numeric summary, i.e. min/max/median/mean rs1 <- psrc_hts_stat(hts_data,                       analysis_unit="trip",                       group_vars="hhsize",                       stat_var="distance_miles")  head(dplyr::select(rs1[survey_year==2023], -c(survey_year, min, max))) #>      hhsize count      mean   mean_moe   median #>       <ord> <int>     <num>      <num>    <num> #> 1: 1 person 10081  6.977442  1.4370516 2.222023 #> 2: 2 people 12719 11.073412  3.2645435 3.135158 #> 3: 3 people  3915  7.009381  0.7154436 3.035398 #> 4: 4 people  3858  6.123352  0.5365826 3.197576 #> 5: 5 people  1152 23.016527 12.1648649 2.116390 #> 6: 6 people   404  5.836721  1.1624158 2.054875  # Calculate a categorical summary, i.e. count/share rs2 <- psrc_hts_stat(hts_data, "trip", c("hhsize", "mode_class_5"))  head(dplyr::select(rs2[survey_year==2023 & as.character(mode_class_5)=="Transit"],                    -c(survey_year, mode_class_5))) #>      hhsize count       prop    prop_moe       est  est_moe #>       <ord> <int>      <num>       <num>     <num>    <num> #> 1: 1 person   850 0.07819693 0.014343472 144804.30 27878.08 #> 2: 2 people   553 0.02450678 0.005668314 121841.55 28456.42 #> 3: 3 people   124 0.01886768 0.006262066  55321.98 18366.04 #> 4: 4 people    80 0.01031612 0.003696247  37591.82 13442.13 #> 5: 5 people    28 0.02357459 0.008536841  35762.24 12806.51 #> 6: 6 people    14 0.05805984 0.028137362  57373.12 28499.56

title: Retrieve and summarize data
text: Since hts_data element data.table, can manipulated combination base r, tidyverse (e.g. mutate()), data.table (e.g :=) syntax. example illustrates adding variables specific hts_data$trip element. Notice, inheritance capability mentioned earlier applies custom variables well, want recode household-level variable feature trip-level analysis, just add hts_data$hh (hts_data$trip). Standard category groupings present base data can added via functions described accompanying vignette. take entire hts_data object argument, specific table (package knows involved). lends piping multiple standard recodes. Keep mind filtering table removes records available subsequent analyses. Rather manage multiple filtered copies data object, may want create new variable relevant table NA values records intend exclude summary. can use incl_na=FALSE option exclude line summary results (particular value want shares calculated reported categories). calculate mode split percentages work trips adding variable coded NA non-work-related trips, using incl_na=FALSE option limit statistics category. Note: travelSurveyTools summary functions require additional preparatory steps psrc.travelsurvey handles , simplicity. use native travelSurveyTools summary functions, ’ll need handle extra steps , since travelSurveyTools dependency psrc.travelsurvey package.
code: library(dplyr) library(stringr)  # Use a standard variable recode to get simpler trip purpose hts_data <- hts_bin_dest_purpose(hts_data)  # Use dplyr::mutate to add a simplified mode field & work purpose specifier hts_data$trip <- mutate(   hts_data$trip,    purpose_work = case_when(     dest_purpose_bin4=="Work" ~ "Work",     !is.na(dest_purpose_bin4) ~ NA_character_) )   # Calculate a categorical summary, i.e. count/share rs3 <- psrc_hts_stat(hts_data, "trip", c("purpose_work", "mode_class_5"), incl_na=FALSE)  head(dplyr::select(rs3[survey_year==2023],                    -c(survey_year, purpose_work))) #>          mode_class_5 count        prop    prop_moe        est    est_moe #>                <char> <int>       <num>       <num>      <num>      <num> #> 1: Bike/Micromobility   172 0.009722362 0.002883724   20617.16   6002.697 #> 2:              Drive  3211 0.865739816 0.018028620 1835881.03 125651.228 #> 3:              Other    99 0.016077561 0.008704412   34093.95  18586.711 #> 4:            Transit   402 0.029027564 0.007653030   61555.62  16093.543 #> 5:               Walk   728 0.079432698 0.013730924  168444.35  29070.846

what: Why rates? A convenient way to examine and compare
title: Summarize trip and VMT rates
text: addition aggregate counts shares, psrc.travelsurvey includes functions calculate average daily trip- VMT (vehicle miles traveled) rates. metrics often used travel analysis modeling. ratio (mean amount per person per day), rates normalized respect population days reported, maintaining unit scale can interpreted compared absolute relative terms. (contrast, shares unit can compared relative terms; counts aren’t normalized can’t meaningfully compared across subgroups surveys.)

title: Summarize trip and VMT rates
text: Trip VMT rates involve summarization day level prior aggregate summarization across respondents, functions: psrc_hts_triprate() psrc_hts_vmtrate() function simplified psrc_hts_stat(); since analysis_unit stat_var fixed/inherent, two arguments: hts_data - hts_data object group_vars - grouping variables, nesting order (share summaries calculated per categories variable listed last). incl_na=FALSE option also available functions.

title: Summarize trip and VMT rates
text: functions rely additional functionality submitted travelSurveyTools package yet merged, ’ll need install branch package: remotes::install_github("RSGInc/travelSurveyTools", ref="add_vmt_rate"). VMT calculated distance, limited vehicular travel, accounts co-travelers, preceding get_psrc_hts() call must include following among survey_vars argument: mode_class trip_distance travelers_total. hts_data object missing one , psrc_hts_vmtrate() report user return NULL. count implicit trip attribute, psrc_hts_triprate() requires additional variables.

title: Summarize trip and VMT rates
code: library(psrc.travelsurvey) library(data.table)  # Specify which variables to retrieve vars <- c("telecommute_freq", "workplace",           "mode_class", "distance_miles", "travelers_total")  # Retrieve the data hts_data <- get_psrc_hts(survey_vars = vars)  # default includes all survey_years hts_data <- hts_bin_telecommute_trichotomy(hts_data)  # Calculate a trip rate rs1 <- psrc_hts_triprate(hts_data, group_vars="telecommute_trichotomy")  head(dplyr::select(rs1[survey_year==2023], -c(survey_year, count, min, max, median))) #>    telecommute_trichotomy     mean  mean_moe #>                    <fctr>    <num>     <num> #> 1:          Fully At Home 3.429360 0.5138521 #> 2:                 Hybrid 4.003980 0.3685396 #> 3:        Fully In Person 4.334025 0.2826659 #> 4:                   <NA> 3.505400 0.1940856  # Calculate a VMT rate rs2 <- psrc_hts_vmtrate(hts_data, "telecommute_trichotomy", incl_na=FALSE)  head(dplyr::select(rs2[survey_year==2023], -c(survey_year, count, min, max, median))) #>    telecommute_trichotomy     mean mean_moe #>                    <fctr>    <num>    <num> #> 1:          Fully At Home 15.78928 2.359958 #> 2:                 Hybrid 24.21145 2.599772 #> 3:        Fully In Person 31.97204 3.300489
